Topic.Title: Misinformation Regaridn Bac.......

Message.Msg: Your information is skewed also. Yes there are now 2 times as many shares, but when BAC had half the shares they did not include Merrill Lynch and Countrywide. These purchases turned out to be a short term mistakes that NEARLY broke the company. But right or wrong with help from Uncle Sam they made it through and now have the earnings power of these additions and they will earn going fwd from here. BAC will have earnings of about 3 dollars per share in just a few short years (not today or tomorrow for those trying to make a buck on a quick trade). In the meantime it is widely puplished that they will probably buy back 10% of the shares by the end of 2014 and then who knows? This will definatly be a 30/share stock in 3-4 years and at the current price for those INVESTING for the long run that is a great return at todays price and many of us are already up 50-100%. Not to mention that the dividend that it will pay IN THE FUTURE will also be a great return on todays investment. GREAT LONG TERM BUY! I may also ad that with the price swings it is not a horrible stock for a short term trade either.

Message.Msg: lets be honest. Who really thinks that the debt ceiling is going to happen. We p#$%$ed a resolution on the fiscal cliff. What did the market do? Brushed it off and actually rallied with flying colors. Now here you have a second issue where the debt ceiling is either going to be raised or addressed and reduced. If the debt ceiling goes up obama is going to get his #$%$ handed to him by both parties. If the ceiling goes up to 25 trillion that is unsustainable and would push the economy and the global economy to into a recession. Europe would get pushed more into recession and any progress they make would be dissolved. I think we will have a resolution in the ceiling and historically speaking the dow can go alot higher past 14k. If you take all this into account mixed with the fact that BAC paid all of its lawsuits off and will just potentially (as in maybe) face lawsuits in the future...I think BAC opens alot higher.

Topic.Title: Help!!!

Message.Msg: The horizon is profit from BAC is months to several years. If your horizon is hours or days or weeks, you should sell. If you can hold onto your investment for a year, or 2, or 3, you are probably going to be rewarded. The market is of course reacting to the huge known expenses the bank has had to make to attempt to emerge from the Countrywide mortgage mess - and there will be more charges in the coming quarters. But once clear of all this - perhaps next year - there is a very strong probability that the value of this stock will increase substantially. Just depends on your time horizon and tolerance for risk.

Message.Title: The Treasury Has Already Minted Two Trillion Dollar Coins(WELCOME to the new US of ZIMABABWE!!!!!)
Message.Msg: Laurence Kotlikoff No doubt, you’ve heard about the latest irresponsible fiscal/monetary proposal to be floated by members of Congress and the erstwhile economist, Paul Krugman, whose lunch was just eaten by Jon Stewart. It entails having the Treasury avoid the federal debt limit by handing the Federal Reserve a single $1 trillion platinum coin. The Fed would then credit the Treasury’s bank account with $1 trillion, which the Fed could spend on the President’s lunch, a $200 toilet seat, a new aircraft carrier, more Medicare spending – anything it wants. Pulling Money Out of Thin Air Is there anything special about platinum? Well, yes. The coin doesn’t have to contain $1 trillion worth of platinum. It can be microscopic for all the Fed cares as long as they can use a electron microscope to read the $1 trillion "In God We Trust" inscription. But it has to be made out of platinum. No other metal or substance, like a piece of pizza, will do. The reason is that the Treasury has the right, by an obscure law, to mint platinum coins, but only platinum coins. Otherwise, making money by making money is the Fed’s domain. Countries that pay for what they spend by printing money or, these days, creating it electronically, are usually broke. That certainly fits our bill. Our country is completely, entirely, and thoroughly broke. In fact, we’re in worst fiscal shape than any developed country, including Greece. We have fantastically large expenditures coming due in the form of Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid payments to the baby boom generations – I.O.U.s, which we’ve conveniently kept off the books. When the boomers are fully retired, Uncle Sam will need to cough up $3 trillion (in today’s dollars) per year to pay us (I’m one of us) these benefits. To put $3 trillion in perspective, it’s 1.5 times Russia’s GDP. These benefits are called entitlements because, presumably, we feel we are entitled to hit up our children to cover their costs. Borrowing from them and l

Topic.Title: The Treasury Has Already Minted Two Trillion Dollar Coins(WELCOME to the new US of ZIMABABWE!!!!!)

Message.Msg: from them and letting them tax themselves and their kids to pay themselves back is a good trick, but it’s running afoul of the debt ceiling. Taxing them more and promising to the pay them benefits they’ll never receive is an old trick that’s run its course. So we’re now onto printing money that will, we hope, raise prices only after we have protected our assets against inflation. We've Been Here Before And we’re printing lots and lots of money. Indeed, over the past five years, the Treasury has, in effect, done its $1 trillion coin trick twice. Come again? Well, substitute a $2 trillion piece of paper called a Treasury bond for the platinum coin. Suppose the Treasury prints up such a piece of paper and hands it to the Fed and the Fed puts $2 trillion into its account. No difference right, except for the lack of platinum. Next suppose the Treasury doesn’t hand the $2 trillion bond to the Fed directly, but hands it to John Q. Public who gives the Treasury $2 trillion and then hands the bond to the Fed in exchange for $2 trillion. What’s the result? It’s the same. The Treasury has $2 trillion to spend. John Q. Public has his original $2 trillion. And the Fed is holding the piece of paper labeled U.S. Treasury bond. Finally, suppose the Treasury does this operation in smaller steps and over five years, specifically between 2007 and today. It sells, i.e., hands to John Q. in exchange for money, smaller denomination bonds, which Johns Q. sells to the Fed, i.e., hands to the Fed in exchange for money. Further, suppose the sum total of all these bond sales to the public and Fed purchases of the bonds from the public equals $2 trillion. Voila, you’ve got U.S. monetary policy since 2007. In 2007, the monetary base – the amount of money our government printed in its 231 years of existence totaled $800 billion. Today it totals $2.8 trillion. And it increased by this amount via the process just described – the Treasury’s effective minting out of thin air two $1 trillion p

Topic.Title: The Treasury Has Already Minted Two Trillion Dollar Coins(WELCOME to the new US of ZIMABABWE!!!!!)

Message.Msg: A Hidden Tax Now what happens when the Treasury spends its freebee money? It raises prices of the goods and services we buy or keeps them from falling as much as would otherwise be the case. Either way, the money we have in our pockets or in the bank or coming to us over time as, for example, interest plus principal on bonds we’ve bought in the past – all this money loses purchasing power. So we are effectively taxed $2 trillion. What the advocates of the $1 trillion coin are, therefore, proposing is to tax us in a hidden way. This is not just taxation without representation. It’s also taxation with misrepresentation. The fact that a Nobel Laureate in economics would propose this without making clear this fact raises the question of whether his prize should be revoked. Lance Armstrong, after all, is losing his medals for discrediting his profession. Perhaps the Nobel committee should consider taking back Krugman’s. This is no innocent omission. Every PhD economist is taught about seigniorage. It’s a term that was coined (excuse the pun) in the 15th century and stems from the right of feudal lords – seignurs – to coin money, use it to buy, say, chickens and debase the purchasing power of the coins they had given their serfs in the past for, say, wild boar. Today, 12 cents out of ever dollar being spent by our government is being printed. As indicated, the money supply has more than tripled. While inflation, let alone hyperinflation, has not yet occurred, everything is in place for this outcome. If you want to see what things will look like, check out Zimbabwe, which has surely been reading Krugman’s articles.

Topic.Title: On Tuesday, January 8, Jim Cramer said on CNBC that BAC is a buy. The next day it collapsed.

Message.Msg: Yeah...ooops on the like. Sometimes I type too fast and do not proof-read (seldom is it the person that actually does from what I've observed on forums like these). However, that said, SHILL is appropriate to the likes of Cramer and most of the ilk on CNBC, etc. A shill, also called a plant or a stooge, is a person who publicly helps a person or organization without disclosing that he has a close relationship with that person or organization. Cramer is like the guy who eggs you on in a game of 3-card monte. His intent is not pure, and certainly NOT in your favor. So long as you know this going in...well...we're all adults here ain't we?

Message.Title: HERE IS WHAT " MODEST" STAND FOR IN THE DICTIONARY.
Message.Msg: mod·est /ˈmädəst/ Adjective Unassuming or moderate in the estimation of one's abilities or achievements. (of an amount, rate, or level of something) Relatively moderate, limited, or small. Synonyms humble - unassuming - unpretentious - lowly - moderate

Topic.Title: Below $11.50

Message.Msg: This whole market looks a little tired. I am hoping to get it around 10.50 or less, but lately, the pullbacks in the market have been very shallow. I keep thinking that the market will correct but it hasn't happened. Not too worried because I am very heavy into stocks anyway, but I would feel comfortable buying back at those levels. I think it will go to 14-16 this year.

Message.Title: A little girl and a Teapublican on a plane
Message.Msg: An Teapublican was seated next to a little girl on an airplane and he turned to her and said, "Do you want to talk? Flights go quicker if you strike up a conversation with your fellow passenger." The little girl, who had just started to read her book, replied to the total stranger, "What would you want to talk about?" " Oh, I don't know," said the Teapublican. How about Gun control, National Debt and Obama , as he smiled smugly. "OK," she said. "Those could be interesting topics But let me ask you a question first. A horse, a cow, and a Deer all eat the same stuff - grass. Yet a deer excretes Little pellets, while a cow turns out a flat patty, but a Horse produces clumps. Why do you suppose that is? The Teapublican, visibly surprised by the little girl's intelligence, thinks about it and says, "Hmmm, I have no idea." To which the little girl replies, "Do you really feel qualified to discuss Gun Control, National Debt, and Obama when you don't know $hit?" And then she went back to reading her book.

Message.Title: BAC poorly run company, get out
Message.Msg: Well I may be in a minority, but I have to believe in the product and or service. I form a gut feeling before i go forward. Well if you are like me, I wouldn't put my faith in BAC. Been a BAC customer 45 years, they gave me my 1st RE loan back when they were pressured to loan to Vietnam vets. In the early 70's. I am compelled to share their incompetence with you so you can evaluate form a different perspective, a BAC customers experience. I've been a loyal BAC customer for over 40 years. I recently applied to refinance my home, that I built 25 years ago, to pull some cash to pay off maturing auto lease option to buy. credit 815 fico, never a day late on any obligation. BofA loan representative informed me that I qualified, no issues, competitive rate, etc. 3 months later BAC loan processor calls and informs me that the loan representative submitted my loan under a wrong program and couldn't honor the amount requested. She advised that I start the process from scratch, hence losing 90 days and most likely having to pay another appraisal fee as mine will no longer be valid to make it through the new loan process, as well as losing my rate lock. My lease option expired. Frustrated to say the lease. Really I have only myself to blame, because after the fact I researched BOfA Mortgage reviews, they were horrendous! BofA it appears has scorched many a good customer. I know I would be interested in this information if I were a BAC investor. Good luck with this loser!

Topic.Title: flippant_1 gonna get taken to the BAC grill-better change her name again

Message.Msg: Nah, bird, I'm starting to think it's better to just let the miscreants wander as far off the reservation as they want. Let winter and the wolves take care of them. After all, It's a strategy that worked just fine against the GOP (remember how encouraging I was to kilgares?), and it shows all the signs of working even better the next time. Besides, flip's surmise that I'm mental was just a lucky guess; I'm sure he doesn't know that I read 3200 words a minute and have a photographic memory; he thinks I'm spending days on end poring over message histories and straining to make a case. As for ze, she still thinks I'm Warren and can't do math. She must have missed my gravitational calculations for that near-earth asteroid. Kay-ryst, you take the time to show your work and half the duh-masses can't follow it. Look, if all the other big financials spent more on legal fees than they earned, how can you blame BAC for jumping off that cliff when all the other kids were doing it? And if BAC is the only one in that position, the most reasonable explanation is that BAC has adopted a business model so brilliant and innovative that the other banks can't understand it (although that WOULD sort of undermine the notion that democraps are to blame for the situation). Either way, GO BAC! ROTFLMAO and as Bullwinkle would add, "....but watch where you're goin'."
